data.title: Hank McGraw, onetime baseball phenom turned maverick and late-life Napan, dead at 81
data.meta_description: Hank McGraw, the baseball pitcher who sacrificed a once-limitless professional career for the sake of his principles, died Saturday at age 81.
data.text:
Updated at 5:27 p.m. Wednesday  Hank McGraw, the baseball player who sacrificed a once-limitless professional career for the sake of his principles, died Saturday at age 81.

McGraw, who had lived in Napa County for about 30 years, died of natural causes at his cottage north of the city, according to his friend Jennifer Brusstar, president and chief executive of the Yountville-based Tug McGraw Foundation named after Hanks late brother, the major league pitching star.

Hanks nephew Tim McGraw, the country music superstar, also announced his uncles passing Wednesday on Facebook.

This weekend we lost the patriarch of the McGraw family. Our beloved Uncle Hank, the singer wrote. He was just an incredible man. He had a way of lighting up any room he walked into without trying. He was a no-bs, straight shooter. Honest and truthful, even if it hurt. A true renaissance man  and more than that, he was a good friend to all who knew him, and he loved with an open heart.

Once a cant-miss prospect as a young lefthanded-hitting catcher in the 1960s, McGraw became far better known as a freethinking free spirit, accepting the eventual cost to his athletic career. Eventually he found his way to Napa, where he became a popular public face for the nonprofit foundation created to honor his younger brother Tug McGraw  a once-scrawny overachiever who became a top big league relief pitcher for 19 years and a beloved baseball personality before his 2004 death from brain cancer.

One brother should have become a baseball star. The other did. Hank McGraw remembers his bond with his sibling, 20 years after his death.

Born in 1943 and raised in Vallejo, Hank McGraw was a multi-sport high school star who received numerous offers to play pro baseball or gain a college football scholarship. Sports, and baseball in particular, formed the glue that connected Hank and Tug, the younger sibling by 19 months.

Nearly 40 years later, Tug well remembered hero worship that lingered even after his own baseball success began to outstrip Hanks. He was All-Everything when I was a kid, and all I ever wanted was to be part of his world, Tug told Sports Illustrated in 2002.

The New York Mets signed the older brother to a contract in 1961, a year before their debut season, after their scout Roy Partee promised Hank the team would also hire his unheralded younger brother upon his high school graduation two years later.

Tug weighed 140, and 11 (other) teams offered me money and they all balked, Hank told the Napa Valley Register in December. Roy was the only one who didnt. I told the Mets, Look, he wont always be a midget  just look at my dad and mom and me; he just hasnt grown yet.

But McGraw traveled a turbulent road through his 12 minor league seasons on 18 different teams, questioning the racism and closed-mindedness he later recalled seeing at nearly every turn. Just three days after joining his first minor-league team in Lexington, North Carolina, his manager spewed N-words at him as he chewed him out for daring to sit and chat with the Black players on the team bus, McGraw told the Register.

"Racism was a serious mind (expletive) for me. I just couldnt ignore it," Hank told Sports Illustrated reporter Gary Smith four decades later. "I ended up in the backs of buses, singing with the Blacks and Latinos. Some managers, when you lost, wanted it so quiet you could hear a rat piss on cotton. I wanted to win, but I cared more about how you played, about the game not ending than about winning or losing.

When he was with ballclubs (and) was told not to fraternize with the African Americans, he chose not to listen to them and continued and stood up for what is right, Brusstar said Wednesday evening. I wanted my children to hear those stories about how he stood up for others and never wavered.

Listen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts

McGraws interests, hobbies and habits also set him apart from other minor leaguers  making bead jewelry for teammates girlfriends, visiting libraries and historic landmarks on road trips, even once singing Bobby Darins Splish Splash after a team loss.

The balance between his baseball ambitions and his personality finally was upended for good in July 1970, while he was batting over .300 for the Eugene (Oregon) Emeralds, a Triple-A club that was the last step before promotion to the Philadelphia Phillies.

A newly hired manager, Lou Kahn, ordered McGraw to cut off his collar-length hair and his ample sideburns. McGraw was 27, with his chances of reaching the big leagues diminishing, but stood his ground and refused to cut his hair unless the Phillies organization demanded the same from all its other players.

McGraws stance earned him a suspension and the effective end of his major league dreams. By 1972, at age 29, his career was over.

His path through life proved as winding as his baseball career had been. By turns he was a leatherworker, a bartender, a gold panner, and even a coach with a Phillies minor league squad. When Tim McGraw broke out into national fame in the 1990s, Hank joined his nephew on three concert tours, becoming a fan favorite in his own right.

Following Tug McGraws death at age 59, Hank McGraw lent his name and face to the foundation created to raise money to improve the quality of life of those living with brain tumors and traumatic brain injuries.

Among the nonprofits fundraising events over two decades have been softball games by the Mixed Nutts team, with a roster drawing on Yountville Veterans Home residents. Hank McGraw became a regular at the teams opening-day contests, throwing out the ceremonial first pitch.

Beyond his service to the Tug McGraw Foundation  whose office is on the Veterans Home campus  Hank McGraw became a friend to many of homes residents, according to Brusstar.

Residents appreciated the story of him not signing his Mets contract unless they signed his baby brother, she said of Hank. That showed the strength of their brotherhood.

The veterans loved hearing his stories of the people he played with, listening to his Hank Aaron stories. We were so privileged to have him show up at the games, sit with the vets. He threw his last (ceremonial) pitch a couple months ago.

Though the siblings life paths had diverged sharply over the decades, the loss of his younger brother weighed heavily on Hank McGraw to the end of his own life.

It was so hard to believe it, because he was still so vibrant, Hank said of Tugs battle with cancer in an interview shortly before his own final birthday. It was hard to believe that he was sick, dying.

He added, quoting Tugs famous slogan: We were all trying to believe. Thats what he kept saying: Ya gotta believe.

In addition to Tim McGraw, survivors include two other nephews, Mark and Matthew, and a niece, Cari Velardo-McGraw. A younger brother of Hank and Tug, Dennis McGraw, died in July 2023.

Memorial arrangements were pending Wednesday night.
